block.p: Nike to Acquire Converse, Merging 2 Footwear Giants Nike, known for its shoes and its swoosh, has Michael Jordan and Tiger Woods on its corporate team. Now it is lining up yet another sports star. For $305 million, Nike is buying Converse, a century-old footwear company and maker of the celebrated ''Chuck Taylor All-Star'' shoe.

The deal brings together one of the oldest names in athletic footwear with perhaps the world's most famous sports shoe brand. It also opens a chapter for the financially troubled Converse, which dominated the athletic footwear business for decades before stumbling into bankruptcy in the early 1990's. [Page C2.]

Viacom Wants Vivendi Cable Assets Sumner M. Redstone, left, the chairman of Viacom, confirmed that his company is seeking to acquire Vivendi Universal's cable television networks but not its film or music studios, effectively relegating him to the second tier of bidders in an auction of the Universal entertainment businesses. The film studio MGM, controlled by the financier Kirk Kerkorian, and NBC are also believed to be bidding. [C3.]
Mixed Feelings on 'Do Not Call' More than 23 million telephone numbers have signed up for the federal do-not-call registry, which takes effect in October. [A1.]

A Report on Global Warming Plans Many of the world's largest companies are doing a poor job of preparing for the business impact of global warming, according to a report prepared by the Investor Responsibility Research Center. [C5.]

Motions Are Filed in Stewart Case A hearing has been scheduled for July 21 on motions filed by lawyers for Martha Stewart. Ms. Stewart will go to trial Jan. 12 on federal securities fraud and obstruction charges. [C5.]

ImClone Systems, the biotechnology company at the center of an insider-trading scandal involving Martha Stewart, says it has returned to compliance with rules governing Nasdaq stock market listings. [C7.]
Drug Costs for Elderly Examined A study by Families USA says prices for the 50 drugs most prescribed for the elderly rose last year at more than three times the rate of inflation. [C2.]
Inventories Decreased 0.3% in May Wholesale inventories fell 0.3 percent in May, to $289.34 billion, the Commerce Department said. [C7.]

Profits and Revenue Climb at Yahoo Profits more than doubled at Yahoo in the second quarter as revenue rose 42 percent. But those results were not enough to satisfy investors. Shares of Yahoo moved up 19 cents, to $35.29, in regular trading. Yahoo, which announced its results after the close of trading, fell to $33 in after-hours trading. [C6.]

Stocks Decline on Profit Taking The Nasdaq composite index inched up 1 point, to 1,747.46, but the Dow Jones industrial average declined 66.88 points, or 0.7 percent, to 9,156.21. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.63 points, to 1,002.21. [C7.]
The Swiss investment bank UBS became the first foreign investor to buy shares on China's dominant Class A share market, which trades in yuan. [World Business, Section W.]

Security Costs Up After 9/11 American corporations have increased their security spending only slightly in response to the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, according to a survey of security personnel. [C11.]
Roche Loses a Round in Court Fight Roche Holding may lose its license to use Igen technology after an appeals court upheld Igen's right to end the contract. [C4.]

The Jobs-Spending Connection Any government stimulus should concentrate on areas that produce a high number of well-paying jobs. Tax cuts for the rich simply will not do it. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. [C2.]
